newsitem.title: CANADA: CBRS confirms Shell Canada ratings.
newsitem.headline: CBRS confirms Shell Canada ratings.

text.p: Canadian Bond Rating Service said on Tuesday it confirmed the ratings on Shell Canada Ltd's commercial paper and debentures at A-1 and A+(Low), respectively, with a stable outlook.
The confirmation by CBRS follows the proposed sale of its chemicals business to a unit of Shell's parent company, Royal Dutch/Shell Group for C$635 million.

CBRS said the rating confirmation reflects low debt leverage and strong production characteristics, in part offset by the company's relatively weaker performance among the integrated companies in Canada.

The bond rating service said the sale of the chemicals unit, which has been one of the major reasons for earnings decline in the first half of 1996, will constrain further operating losses and enable Shell Canada to exploit advantages in the upstream resources sector and lift the performance of its downstream oil products sector where margins have been negatively affected since the second quarter of 1996.
CBRS said the sale will further enhance the strong financial flexibility Shell enjoys after a buoyant performance in 1994/95 and the sale of its polypropylene unit in 1995.

It said the sale will enable Shell to pursue projects in the resources area, including the development of oil sands liquids project and the Sable Island natural gas project, in which it has 23-percent interest.
CBRS said the stable outlook represents Shell's high leverage to natural gas production, improved capacity of total liquids production and the maintenance of debt leverage below 20 percent.
